about.help: Transcription Models was retrieved from Youtube from the channel J. Christopher Anderson, and was created on 9/25/2013.

contents.params: The first decade of synthetic biology emphasized quantitative control of gene expression.  To enable such control, there are several models to predict gene expression levels.  Here we examine those that model transcription.

The most basic type of promoter you can have in a prokaryote are constitutive promoters. These promoters initiate mRNA synthesis independent of the influence of regulation.  The term 'constititive expression' is more commonly defined as 'Expression of a gene that is transcribed at a constant level'. This idea of 'constant' expression turns out to be a very fuzzy concept that our field still grapples with.  In practice, transcription rates depend highly on the physiology of the cell, and thus in practice one never observes true 'constant' or even 'consistent' expression.  Thus, I'll give it a more concrete but specific biochemistry-based definition -- a constitutive promoter is one whose observed states only include free and sigma-factor-bound species.
Relative Promoter Units is one strategy for encapsulating the strength of a promoter.

Constitutive promoters are great when you just want something simple in your design and aren't worried about dynamics or toxicity of your proteins.  Often, however, you will want some regulation, and for this you'll need to use more complicated promoters.

We've already talked about why you might want to use an inducible promoter, but nature uses promoters in more nuanced ways than this.  Incorporation of these regulation mechanisms into genetic devices is current topic of study.
